AuxEcoSys: Temperate Pacific Tidal Salt and Brackish Marsh
Temperate Pacific Tidal Salt and Brackish Marsh

references.N75NEW01USGP: Newby, T. C. 1975. A sea otter (Enhydra lutris) food dive record. The Murrelet 56:19.
references.A04BOD01USGP: Bodkin, J.L., G.G. Esslinger, and D.H. Monson. 2004. Foraging depths of sea otters and implications to coastal marine communities. Marine Mammal Science, 20(2):305-321.
references.A12MAL01USGP: Maldini, D., R. Scoles, R. Eby, M. Cotter, and R.W. Rankin. 2012. Patterns of sea otter haul-out behavior in a California tidal estuary in relation to environmental variables. Northwestern Naturalist, 93(1):67-78.
references.A09LAI01USGP: Laidre, K.L., R.J. Jameson, E. Gurarie, S.J. Jeffries, and H. Allen. 2009. Spatial habitat use patterns of sea otters in coastal Washington. Journal of Mammalogy, 90(4):906-917.
references.A11GIL01USGP: Gilkinson, A.K., S.E. Finerty, F. Weltz, T.M. Dellapenna, and R.W. Davis. 2011. Habitat associations of sea otters (Enhydra lutris) in a soft- and mixed-sediment benthos in Alaska. Journal of Mammalogy, 92(6):1278-1286.

habitat_description: Sea otters inhabit near shore waters, typically within 2 km of shore (Gilkinson et al., 2011), though adult males are known to forage at distances as great as 3500 m (Laidre et al., 2009). Their foraging habitat is defined best by water depth, with most foraging taking place in waters <30m (Bodkin et al., 2004), though dives have been observed at depths up to 100 m (Newby, 1975; Bodkin et al., 2004). While displaying preference for kelp forests and waters over rocky substrate (Kvitek and Oliver, 1988; Gerber et al., 2003; Gilkinson et al., 2011), sea otters have been observed foraging in waters with sand and mud substrates as well (Kvitek et al., 1988; Kvitek and Oliver, 1988; Laidre et al., 2002). Additionally, the species is known to haul out on small beaches (Maldini et al., 2002).
